Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Allow the user to select precisely the code he wants" (#8886) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

Hello,

You can't select precisely the text you want in the "command" box.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4760796/142740240-77277e23-4a71-4002-88cf-bd5800e82fd0.mp4

This is annoying when you already have the manifest set up in your repo and just want to copy the second line.

Fix: 

On the CSS class `install-command-row`, remove all the rules about `user-select: all;`

If the user, wants to copy the whole snippet he can use the Copy button on the right.

### Repro Steps

1. Open https://www.nuget.org/packages/fantomas-tool/4.6.0-alpha-008
2. Click on .NET CLI (local)
3. Try to select only the second line



### Expected Behavior

You should be able to select only the second line if you want

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[TFM Display] Create model for badges and table from compatible frameworks." (#8881) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This model will be used on the display page to create the table and badges for UI.

* `FrameworkCompatibilityService` was updated to include a supported framework that is not on the `SupportedFrameworks` list. This to include all package asset frameworks that we might not know of (but they are not used to get new computed frameworks, so no computation added here).
* `PackageFrameworkCompatibilityFactory` creates the model that holds the badges and table ready to be displayed.
  * Badges: Contains the lowest package asset framework (we are not considering computed frameworks for this) that are part of .NET framework product.
  * Table: The key is the product framework name, and the values are lists of compatible frameworks (already ordered).

Address: https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3991.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.Client code calls string.Replace and ignores the return value" (#10477) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet.Client's `src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.PackageManagement/Utility/PackagesConfigLockFileUtility.cs` calls `string.Replace` and doesn't do anything with the return value.

```csharp
if (Path.DirectorySeparatorChar != '/')
{
    lockFileRelativePath.Replace('/', Path.DirectorySeparatorChar);
}
```

`string.Replace` doesn't modify the instance; it returns a new string. We should either store the returned value somewhere, or not call `string.Replace` at all.

Product version: 

Worked before? Not sure.

## Repro steps and/or sample project

Opened issue "[DCR]: improve HTTP authentication flow for package sources" (#11402) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Current Behavior

VS doesn't appear to have a well-defined UI for prompting for NuGet package source credentials. For some (not all?) users, there was a message in **Output** that simply asked the user to use interactive mode for authentication. This is cumbersome, because an IDE _is_ already the interactive mode, and it isn't clear for a user how to proceed.

Instead, the answer appears to be: ignore the IDE and instead use the CLI tooling to edit the source and enter credentials there.

### Desired Behavior

Ideally, Tools | Options | NuGet | Sources would have additional UI, such as a `[x] This source requires credentials` checkbox. Either, ticking it reveals further `Login` / `Password` fields, or, they come up as a dialog the first time you try to access that source.

### Additional Context

We recently moved a NuGet server that used to be behind a VPN to a public machine, but behind HTTP authentication.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[DCR]: NuGet.VisualStudio and NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts to follow Visual Studio version numbers" (#11394) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Current Behavior

The packages `NuGet.VisualStudio` and `NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts`, which define the interfaces for our Visual Studio extensibility, follow NuGet's version numbers. This follows Visual Studio's version numbers, but 11.0 versions behind. For example, NuGet 6.0 shipped in Visual Studio 2012 17.0. NuGet 5.11 shipped in Visual Studio 2019 16.11.

Additionally, the assemblies matched the build number, just like the rest of NuGet's assemblies. In other words, in build 6.0.0.280, all assemblies had the version 6.0.0.280. In NuGet build 5.11.0.10 has assembly version 5.11.0.10.

### Desired Behavior

The package version for the Visual Studio extensibility APIs should match the version (at least the major and minor version) of Visual Studio that those APIs are available in. For example, the package version for NuGet APIs that are available in dev 17.1 should be package version 17.1.x

Additionally, the assembly version for all builds in the same Major.Minor.Patch should use the same assembly version, to avoid binding redirect issues, similar to how Newtonsoft.Json use the same assembly version for all packages with the same major version.

### Additional Context

NuGet.VisualStudio 6.0.0 did not work when Visual Studio 2022 17.0 was first released, for reasons explained in this issue: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11367.

While the primary goal is to ensure this type of error can never happen again, we can take the opportunity to reduce confusion about which version of NuGet's APIs should be used in which version of Visual Studio.
